title: Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS)
description: Clinical scale used to assess level of consciousness and neurological function in patients with acute brain injury. Evaluates three components: eye opening response (1-4), verbal response (1-5), and motor response (1-6) for a total score ranging from 3-15

parameters.name: eye_opening
parameters.description: Eye opening response. Assesses level of arousal and brainstem function

parameters.name: verbal_response
parameters.description: Verbal response. Assesses cognitive function, orientation, and language abilities

parameters.name: motor_response
parameters.description: Motor response. Assesses motor function and ability to follow commands

result.name: gcs_total_score
result.description: Total Glasgow Coma Scale score (3-15 points)

ranges.interpretation: Severe brain injury with significant impairment of consciousness. Patient is comatose and unable to follow commands. Requires intensive monitoring and may need intubation and mechanical ventilation.
Moderate brain injury with altered level of consciousness. Patient may be drowsy or obtunded but can open eyes and localize painful stimuli. Close neurological monitoring required.
Mild brain injury or normal consciousness. Patient is awake and can follow directions. May have mild confusion but maintains ability to communicate and respond appropriately.

references: Teasdale G, Jennett B. Assessment of coma and impaired consciousness. A practical scale. Lancet. 1974;2(7872):81-84. doi: 10.1016/s0140-6736(74)91639-0.
Teasdale G, Maas A, Lecky F, Manley G, Stocchetti N, Murray G. The Glasgow Coma Scale at 40 years: standing the test of time. Lancet Neurol. 2014;13(8):844-854. doi: 10.1016/S1474-4422(14)70120-6.

Brennan PM, Murray GD, Teasdale GM. Simplifying the use of prognostic information in traumatic brain injury. Part 1: The GCS-Pupils score: an extended index of clinical severity. J Neurosurg. 2018;128(6):1612-1620. doi: 10.3171/2017.12.JNS172780.
formula: Total GCS = Eye Opening Score (1-4) + Verbal Response Score (1-5) + Motor Response Score (1-6). Range: 3-15 points
notes: Developed by Graham Teasdale and Bryan Jennett in 1974
Most widely used neurological assessment tool internationally
Motor component is the most predictive of outcome
Should be documented showing individual component scores (e.g., GCS 15 [E4, V5, M6])
Modified versions exist for pediatric patients and intubated patients
Use modifiers when applicable: T for intubated (unable to assess verbal), C for eyes closed due to swelling
Serial assessments more valuable than single measurements
Lower scores indicate more severe neurological impairment
Score of 8 or less typically indicates need for airway protection
Limitations include inability to assess in intubated patients or those with language barriers
Should be performed by trained healthcare professionals
Part of standard neurological examination in emergency and critical care settings
